tr.td: THE VOLTAGE EMPLOYED IN THIS EQUIPMENT ARE SUFFICIENTLY HIGH TO ENDANGER THE HUMAN LIFE
BEFORE SERVICING OF EQUIPMENT AND GREAT CARE MUST BE TANEN WHILE MAKING INTERNAL ADJUSTMENTS
THE OPENING OF FRONT PANEL DOOR OF THIS EQUIPMENT WILL EXPOSE DANGEROUS VOLTAGES. NO UNAUTHORISED OR UNSKILLED PERSON SHOULD BE PERMITTED ACCESS TO THE INTERIORS OF THE PANEL.
DO NOT ATTEMPT TO ADJSUT OR SERVICE RELAY, WITHOUT FIRST ISOLATING THEM FROM THE SUPPLY.
THE CONTROL UNIT IS EQUIPPED WITH A MODE SELECTOR SWITCH, PUTTING MODE SELECTOR SWITCH TO 3RD POSITION "SHUT OFF" WILL SHUT DOWN THE PLANT IMMEDIATELY.

ul.li: Read operator manual before starting.
Trained operator only to operate the plant.
Live functional tests, repair, maintenance of the electrical systems and the RO plant to be undertaken by personnel fully aware about the equipment and with necessary precautions.
Before any operation is carried out on the osmosis unit, electrical 3-phased power supply must imperatively be insulated.
Operators must respect elementary security and safety rules.
During cleaning operations, ALWAYS WEAR a protective mask, rubber gloves and an apron when working with chemical products, and follow handling instructions for each product.
If any problem occurs, give first aid depending on the chemical product used.
For any electrical operation, the operator must be qualified for work on low voltage electrical equipment.
Do not start the Ro plant without Checking start up requirement and ensuring the position of valves.

section.id: FIRST AID IN CASE OF ELECTRIC SHOCK

title.id: FIRST AID IN CASE OF ELECTRIC SHOCK

section.title: FIRST AID IN CASE OF ELECTRIC SHOCK

td.h4: FIRST AID IN CASE OF ELECTRIC SHOCK

tr.td: 1. SWITCH OFF. If this is not possible, PROTECT YOURSELF with dry insulating material and pull the victim clear of the conductor. DO NOT TOUCH THE VICTIM WITH YOUR BARE HANDS until he is clear of the conductor, but DO NOT WASTE TIME.

td.para: 2. (a) Place the victim in the supine position.

(b) Keep the air passages clear turning the head to one side, opening the patient’s mouth & clearing it of water, saline, mucus or blood, a lot of which might have accumulated in the back of the throat. (Fig. 1)

3. If the jaw is rigid try to force the mouth open by pressure on the gum behind the last molar tooth of the lower jaw. When the upper air passages are thus cleared, tilt the head backward and force the jaw in front of the ears. This would prevent mechanical obstructions to the upper air passages. (Fig. 2-3)
4. (a) Then hold the chin up and forward with one hand pinch the nostrils of the victim with the other (Fig. 4)

(b) Take a very deep breath and apply your mouth to that of the victim and blow into his mouth, until the chest of the victim moves up indicating filling of the lungs. (NEVER ALLOW THE CHIN TO SAG) (Fig. 4)
5. When the chest has moved up, withdraw your mouth and allow the chest to slink back.

REPEAT this process every three to four seconds until the victim begins to breathe again or until he is taken over by a medical attendant. This method can be continued in an ambulance during transit of the patient from the site of accident to the nearest medical centre.
HAVE SOMEONE ELSE SEND FOR A DOCTOR
KEEP PATIENT WARM AND LOOSEN HIS CLOTHING.
DO NOT GIVE LIQUIDS UNTIL THE PATIENT IS CONSCIOUS.

content.para: Based on Reverse Osmosis principle, the desalination plant model NSWRO 40, produces 40 m³/24h of fresh water from sea water at 25°c temperature and 36g/L (36000 PPM) salinity. The produced water flow depends on the salinity and temperature of sea water. The drinking water produced presents a maximum TDS concentration of 500 ppm.

When two solutions of different concentration are separated by a semi-permeable membrane, solvent of less concentrated solution circulates through the membrane to the more concentrated solution to dilute it. With sea water with natural osmotic circulation is the more salted solution (Diag.2A)

In trying to stop the incoming water flow by applying pressure on the concentrated solution, the incoming water flow will decrease and due to the applied pressure, the incoming flow will eventually become non-existent. This balanced pressure is called osmotic pressure (Diag. 2B). This pressure will be 28 bar for seawater at 35000 ppm, evaluated at 0.8 bar/gr of dissolved salts per liter of water.

An increase in pressure above the osmotic pressure is rendered by the passage of a solvent (fresh water), contained in the more concentrated solution (seawater), through the semi-permeable membrane. Towards the diluted solution: this is the Reverse Osmosis phenomenon (Diag. 2C) In order to obtain a useful output, it is necessary to operate at pressure over or equal to twice the osmotic pressure.
The fresh water produced is called "Permeate". The concentrated solution, brine or "Concentrate", which doesn’t pass through the membrane, is rejected into the sea.
Conception of a spiral membrane (see diagram – spiral winding unit)

The semi-permeable membrane in the form of a flat sheet (6) is used as a cover to contain the production vessel (3) and its polyester grid (7) which recuperates the permeate. This formed pile up is sealed to its 3 sides (6 and6) to keep the cover hermetic. Under the effect of pressure, the water purified of its dissolved salts goes through the membrane and is collected on the fine grid (7) up to the central manifold (3) through passage holes (4).

This made up covering together with a spacer (5) are wound in spiral on the production vessel. The sea water (1) entering from one side of the membrane circulates in the spacer tangential to the active surface and comes out on the other side as brine (2). The permeate going through the membrane ends up in the central manifold vessel (3) and is evacuated either by the one or the other end of this tube.
Each membrane represents a surface exchange of 8m2, which enables to obtain an average permeate flow of 200 liters/hour in nominal conditions.
The RO plant must be used as follows: if not, this may alter the plant’s performance or even cause damage

The plant must not operate in an atmosphere exceeding 50°C. It would maintain its integrity in an atmosphere of 55°C, but in that case, it is strongly advised not to operate it in order to avoid exceeding limited temperature of HP pump.
The temperature of the water to be treated must not exceed 35°C.
Water contained in the membrane must not freeze otherwise the membrane will be damaged.
If the plant is to be stored at a temperature lower than 0°C, proceed with “anti-freeze storage”.

para.h4: Nature of water to be treated:

content.para: Low-salinity seawater: In seawater with salinity under 35g/l, this production limit is obtained at less pressure. In low-salinity water, it is normal that the operating pressure is less than the plant’s rated performance.

Chlorinated water: Chlorine Content in water used for flushing and cleaning operations should be < 0.1ppm. It should therefore imperatively be filtered through the included carbon activated filter to be replaced once every 2 years at least.
Chlorine Content in Feed Water should be < 0.1ppm.

td.h4: Maximum Production must not be exceeded 40 m³/24 hours

content.para: The volume of the membrane permeate must be limited to 21 liters per m² of installed membrane, otherwise the membrane cannot prevent the passage of higher concentrations of dissolved salts.
Refer P&I; Diagram VEPL/22-23/SMR-019 REV.01.

para.h6: The PLC insures the complete automatic functioning of the R/O unit and below functions.

content.para: Automatic starting up and stopping according to the ON/OFF manual orders.
Adjusting pressure by closing & opening of servo valve.
Continuous control over the produced fresh water quality and piloting of the dumping valve.
Supervision of all securities and alarms:
Pressure and flow,
Produced water salinity,
Electrical overload on the motors.
Automatic membrane rinsing at the end of production cycle.
The sea water feed pump P10 should be installed as close as possible to the main RO unit, preferably within its operating parameters.
Recommend to have a dedicated sea water feed line to RO sea water feed pump P10.
The piping from the sea chest to the feed pump must be as direct as possible and with the correct diameter.
The pressure at the NETWORK FRESH WATER INLET should be between 3-4 bar to insure a proper membrane rinsing.
The freshwater generator concentrate outlet- BRINE REJECT should be connected to a dedicated over board line.
Clean the pipe line.
First fill the pump casing with water.
Check the direction of rotation.
Tightening of foundation motors.
Fill Oil (ISO VG 68) in bearing case until level.

para.h6: Loading of Sand in Media Filter

content.para: Disconnect the pipes from the head of the filter.
Remove the top head of the sand filter.
Fill the filter with water up to between 1/2 of the height.
Fill the coarse sand 300 Kg first and wait until it has settled at the bottom of the filter.
Remove the sealing put on P and re-assemble the head FLT.SND.185 of the filter tank.
Connect the pipes to the head of the filter.

para.h6: High Pressure Pump Oil Fill up (HP Pump)

td.para: Tools - Standard mechanical tools.
Oil recovery tank Consumables.
HP Pump oil - CON.HP.236 – 2.5 Ltrs.

content.para: See diagram above. Take out the oil stick (3), clean it with clean cloth and put it back to take the measure. Take the stick out and check that the oil level is right, situated between the mini and maxi marks. Top up oil level if necessary.
Place the drainage tank under the drainage hole of pump (2). Take out drain plug, filling plug and drain oil. Scrap the seal of drain plug, place the plug with new seal.
Fill the pump with oil and ensure the correct oil level by seeing it through sight glass.

The dosing pump has a nominal injection value of 6 liters/hour at 100% (6000 gm / hour). Anti-scalant agent requirements are around 2 ppm (2 grams / m³ / hour) for a sea water flow of 4.8 m³/ hour injection will be 9.6 grams/hour.
Fill the tank up with pure anti-scalant solution, install the suction tube and close the tank. Set the dosing percentage to 0.2%.
Consumable Part No: CONS.1002
Package: 25 liters.
Expiry: 2 years from the date of manufacturing if stored in dry and well-ventilated place.
SMBS agent requirements are around 2 ppm (2 grams / m³ / hour) for a sea water flow of 4.8 m³/ hour injection will be 9.6 grams/hour.

Take 25 Ltrs of RO permeate and add 1 pack (6.00 Kg) of SMBS powder supplied and stir it well until the powder gets dissolved completely. Then pour this solution to SMBS dosing tank. Necessary personal protective equipment should be used and utmost care to be taken by operator while preparing chemical solution.
Fill the tank with prepared SMBS chemical. The dosing rate of this solution is 42 ml / hour.
The dosing pump has a nominal injection value of 6 liters/hour at 100% (6000 gm / hour). So set the dosage percentage knob of pump to 0.7%.
Consumable Part No: CONS.1006
Package: 6.0 Kgs.
Expiry: 2 years from the date of manufacturing if stored in dry and well-ventilated place.

td.para: Tools – Neutralite filter spanner.
Neutralite: CONS.NTR.359 – 25 Kg x 2 bags.

content.para: Disconnect the header pipes of neutralite / DA filter. Open the Filter top head of filter.
Make sure the top of the pipe P (see STRAINER SUB-ASSEMBLY in the drawing pic.6) is sealed so no sand can go in it.
Fill 50 Kgs (25 Kgs x 2 bags) of neutralite agent.
The consumption of neutralite is 20 gm/ m3 of product water. 50 Kgs of neutralite can last for approximately 2 months (1440 running hours).
Refer P&ID;: VEPL/22-23/SMR-019 REV.01.

Drain of CIP tank and Fresh water tank to be thrown to bilge.

caution.para: It is always advised to install necessary relief valves, check valves in ship’s piping system in order to safe guard the piping system of RO plant in case of over pressure due to closing of ship side valves.

content.para: Installed power: 20 Kw/40 Amps, 415 V, 3 Ph – 50 Hz.

Network Fresh water from Ship at a pressure of 4 bar.

td.h6: Before Starting of RO unit, make Sure all Valves on Ro plant are in Production mode and All Ships Network Valves are open

content.para: There are 2 Operating modes,

td.h6: MANUAL MODE IS ONLY FOR SERVICE ACTIVITIES; IT MUST NOT BE USED FOR PRODUCTION.

content.para:
In manual Operation mode, pumps can be started manually by Pressing respective pump’s push button. To avail the manual mode, select the operating mode selector rotary switch to “
MANUAL”. Note, in manual mode other control and monitoring systems of RO plant will be isolated from PLC controller, thus it is purely a manual mode. Care to be taken when operating in manual mode, pumps should not run-in dry condition.
Selecting the OPERATING MODE selector knob to POS.3 will shut down the RO unit completely. This shall be used in case of extreme emergency only.
In Auto Operation there are four operating modes;

tr.td: For Membrane Rinsing during service or maintenance.

content.para: In Automatic Operation all control and monitoring of PLC controller will be enabled.
Position the Mode selector rotary switch (PIC.7) to “AUTO” and required mode of operation to be selected in HMI display (PIC.8)

ul.li: Select “PRODUCTION” tab in HMI panel.
Make sure that all valves are positioned as per the Valve position chart displayed in HMI / Valve position chart available on in front of RO panel.
Press “START” tab in HMI, Sea water feed water pump (P10) will start. High pressure Pump P20 will start provided feedback of pressure switch P10 is above 0.5 bar.

Valve PR2 will start closing automatically. The valve will close till 20 bar continuously after 20 bar it will closing in pulse mode. The valve will stop closing once the fresh water flow reaches the desired rate i.e. 1650 in flow meter FL2.
If the permeate flow at permeate flow meter FL2 is 1667 Liters/hour and HP pressure is below 68 bar (PS20 setting) then the plant will run continuously in production mode.
The control valve will close at an interval of every 30 minutes to correct the flow and bring back the desired fresh water flow to 1667 Liters/hour.
If pressure does not reach above 0.5 bar within 2 minutes, plant will trip with alarm as “FEED WATER SHORTAGE”.
If any high-pressure switches PS20, PS30, PS 40 detect high pressure, then the PLC will not initiate the cycle.

If the feed water pressure is above 0.5 bar, High pressure pump P20 and Anti-scalant dosing unit DPS-1 and SMBS dosing DPS2 will start. After the High-pressure pump motor switched to delta, the control valve PR2 start closing automatically. PR2 closing till 20 bar continuously then it closes till achieving the fresh water flow of 1667 liters/ hours in pulse mode. If the pressure reaches 65 bar even the flow is not being achieved the valve stops closing. If pressure exceeds above 68 bar in pressure Gauge Pi6, upon the feedback from PS 20 plant will trip with alarm as “High pressure Fault”.

If the Hp pressure is below 65 bars, as soon as the permeation takes place, the magnetic float of fresh water flow meter FL2 will rise. There is a Flow switch FS10 is installed on FL2, if the float of FL2 rises above the set point of switch FS10 that is 1667 Liters/hour then the plant will trip after 2 minutes of high flow detection with alarm as “HIGH PERMEATE FLOW”. If the permeate flow at permeate flow meter FL2 and HP pressure is 65 bar (PS20 setting) then the plant will run continuously. The control valve closes and correct the fresh water flow at an interval of 30 minute.
If RO permeate conductivity at conductivity meter CM 10 is within set limit that is 1000 micro siemens (500 ppm) then PLC will open Solenoid valve SV2 for permeate transfer to fresh water tank (FT).

If the permeate conductivity is higher than the set point which is 1000 micro siemens (500 ppm), PLC will close SV2 & high conductivity permeate will be diverted to overboard through pressure relief valve PR1. If the permeate conductivity is above set value for 20 minutes, plant will trip with alarm as “HIGH CONDUCTIVITY FAULT”.

Fresh water pump P30 will start upon water reaches the level switch HLS1 of fresh water tank FT. Once the water level is below low-level switch LLS2, fresh water pump will stop. It starts and stops continuously in cyclic upon level of fresh water tank
By pressing “STOP & RINSE” button on HMI, the pressure regulating valve PR2 will open completely and HP pump P20 will stop and after 5 sec time delay, Feed pump P10 will stop.

Once the feed pump P10 is stopped after 5 seconds, Solenoid valve SV1 will on & fresh water rinsing will be carried out. When fresh water rinsing it can either stopped by pressing “STOP “button or it will stop automatically after 5 mins.

section.id: MEMBRANE RINSE MODE FOR SERVICE MAINTENANCE

title.id: MEMBRANE RINSE MODE FOR SERVICE MAINTENANCE

section.title: MEMBRANE RINSE MODE – FOR SERVICE MAINTENANCE

ul.li: Select “RINSE” tab in the HMI display.

Make sure that all valves are positioned as per the Valve position chart displayed in HMI / Valve position chart available on front of RO panel. Keep the Pressure Regulating valve PR2 completely open.
Press “START” tab. Solenoid valve SV1 will open for 5 minutes. Cycle will stop after 5 minutes or it can be stopped by pressing “STOP “tab.

section.id: CIP MODE CHEMICAL CLEANING OF MEMBRANES

title.id: CIP MODE CHEMICAL CLEANING OF MEMBRANES

section.title: CIP MODE (CHEMICAL CLEANING OF MEMBRANES)

content.para: CIP mode should be carried out for every 1000 hours using chemicals or recommended when drop in design permeate flow / Production of membranes
Chemical cleaning is a 7-step process.

ol.li: High PH cleaning with Alkaline cleaner MC11 chemical.
Low PH cleaning with Acid MC 3 chemical.
High PH cleaning with Alkaline cleaner MC 11 chemical.

tr.td:
Chemical cleaning kit
(Each kit contains 5 Kg of MC11 and 2.5 Kg of MC3)

section.id: STEP 1 - FRESH WATER RINSING OF MEMBRANES

title.id: STEP 1 - FRESH WATER RINSING OF MEMBRANES

section.title: STEP 1 - FRESH WATER RINSING OF MEMBRANES.

ul.li: Select “RINSE” mode tab in HMI display.
Make sure that all valves are positioned as per the Valve position chart displayed in HMI / Valve position chart available on in front of RO panel.
Press “START” tab. The pressure regulating valve PR2 open completely. Solenoid valve SV1 will open for 5 minutes. Cycle will stop after 5 minutes.

section.id: STEP 2 - HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL

title.id: STEP 2 - HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL

section.title: STEP 2 - HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL.

ul.li: Fill CIP tank CT with 100 Liters of RO produced water by opening valve V5.
Add 2.5 Kg of MC 11 chemical. To make easy dilution, it is advised to prepare the mixture in 10 liters of water and to add this 10-liter water into tank CT.
Keep the pressure regulating valve PR2 completely open.
Select “CIP” tab in the HMI display (Ref.Pic.10). Set the valve position shown in Pic.10/ Valve position chart available on in front of RO panel.
Press” START” tab. HP pump will start and run for 20 minutes. Chemical contained water will be circulated to membrane modules in closed loop. After 20-minute cycle will stop automatically.
Drain CT tank by opening valve V5.

section.id: STEP 3 - FRESH WATER RINSING OF MEMBRANES

title.id: STEP 3 - FRESH WATER RINSING OF MEMBRANES

section.title: STEP 3 - FRESH WATER RINSING OF MEMBRANES.

ul.li: Follow STEP 1.

section.id: STEP 4 -LOW PH CLEANING WITH MC3 CHEMICAL

title.id: STEP 4 -LOW PH CLEANING WITH MC3 CHEMICAL

section.title: STEP 4 -LOW PH CLEANING WITH MC3 CHEMICAL.

ul.li: Follow STEP. 2. “HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL” but add LOW PH chemical MC 3 in CT tank instead of MC11.
Follow STEP 1.

section.id: STEP 6 -HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL.

title.id: STEP 6 -HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL.

section.title: STEP 6 -HIGH PH CLEANING WITH MC 11 CHEMICAL.

content.para: Follow STEP 2.
Follow STEP 1.

ul.li: Complete a Membrane Fresh Water Rinsing as per STEP.1 of CHEMICAL CLEANING PROCEDURE.
Open valve V5 and fill the CIP tank 100 Liters. Add 1 pack of Preservation chemical (Part No.CON.1004) into 100 liters of water.
Select “CIP” tab in the HMI display (Ref.Pic.10). Set the valve position shown in Pic.10/ Valve position chart available in front of RO panel.
Press” START” tab. HP pump will start and run for 20 minutes. Chemical contained water will be circulated to membrane modules in closed loop. After 20 minutes cycle will stop automatically.
Drain CT tank by opening valve V5.
Switch OFF the main incomer breaker of RO plant.

content.para: When restart the plant after storage, it is necessary to carryout 3 times membrane fresh water rinsing.
Follow STEP.1 of Chemical cleaning procedure for membrane fresh water rinsing.
Backwashing of Sand Filter to be performed once in a week or when the system alarms as “SAND FILTER CLOGGED”., a backwash cycle should be performed as described below.
First Sand Filter Backwash and then Rinsing to be performed to clean the sand filter.

ul.li: Select “BACKWASH” tab on HMI.
Place the valves to BACKWASH POSITION as Shown in Valve position chart available at front of RO panel.
Press “START” tab, Feed water pump (P10) will start and desired cleaning operation will take place.
Cycle will stop after 10 minutes or it can be stopped by pressing “STOP” button.
Place the valves to RINSE POSITION as Shown in Valve position chart available at front of RO panel.
Press “START” tab, Feed water pump (P10) will start and desired cleaning operation will take place.
It may require that the Sand filter cleaning cycle may be performed more than one time to clean the sand filter clogging.

tr.td: “230 v AC ON” or “24 VDC ON” lamps are not glowing.

td.para: Upstream supply is not available.
Voltage relay Oe1 detects voltage fluctuation or phase failure from main incomer.
Bulbs burnt out.
Check that the main is available
Check the presence of voltage and measure voltage at RYB terminals.
Check breaker e2.
Check for any short circuits.
Replace bulbs.

tr.td: “230 v AC ON” or “24 VDC ON” lamps are glowing. But no reaction after pressing “START” of any mode in HMI.
The mode selector rotary switch b1 is either in not used position or in “MANUAL” position.
Position the mode selector switch to AUTO mode.
“230 v AC ON” or “24 VDC ON” lamps are glowing. But no reaction after pressing “START” button of any pump.
The mode selector rotary switch b1 is either in “Not used position” or in “AUTO “position.
Position the mode selector switch to “MANUAL” mode.
GENERAL FAULT lamp is glowing and in HMI “ELECTRICAL FAULT”.

td.para: Overload of any pump.
Electronic Over Current Relay 1e2, 2e2 or 3e2 calibration fault.
Electrical motor fault.
Check the setting of EOCR 1e2, 2e2 or 3e2.
Check insulation of motor winding.

tr.td: No 230 V AC supply ON or 24 V DC supply ON.

td.para: Upstream supply is not available.
Voltage relay Oe1 detects voltage fluctuation or phase failure from main incomer.
“Supply on” signal bulb burnt out
Check that main (electric network) is available.
Check the e1 breaker and change it if necessary.
Check the e2 breaker and change it if necessary.
Check the presence of 24V AC at the bulb terminals. Replace the bulb.

tr.td: SUPPLY ON is glowing. No reaction after pressing the START button.
Auto / manual knob may be in third position which is NOT USED.

td.para: "GENERAL FAULT” is on.
"ELECTRICAL FAULT" message on the PLC screen
Tripping of the EOCRs 1e2, 2e2, or 3e2.
Calibration fault.
Electric motors fault.
Check the switch setting of EOCR
If the fault persists; check the insulation and the motor winding.

tr.td: In production mode, The feed Pump does not start after pressing “ START”.
The regulating valve PR2 fully opened feedback is not available.
Check the feedback chain of regulating valve PR2.
Normal starting of the "FW PUMP" (P10), but not followed by the start of the "HP PUMP" (P20).

td.para: No information returns from the "LP PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS10).
Problem on the measuring chain from the "LP PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS10).
Check the measuring chain and/or adjust the setting of the "LP PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS10).
If adjustment is impossible, replace the "LP PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS10).

tr.td: "GENERAL FAULT" is on. "FEED WATER SHORTAGE" Fault message on the PLC screen

td.para: Water shortage at the HP pump (P20) inlet.
After starting the "HP PUMP" (P20), the feed pressure goes below 0.5bar on the "PRESSURE GAUGE 5μ" (PiI0).
After starting the "HP PUMP" (P20), booster pressure doesn’t go above 0.5bar on the "5μ PRESSURE GAUGE" (Pi10).
Check that upstream valves are opened, and/or pre-filtration chain is clogged; it is necessary
Then to backwash the sand filter and/or to replace the 20μ cartridge filter and/or to replace the 5μ filtration cartridge.
Check the electric measuring chain "LP PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS10) and adjust the threshold back to 0.5 bar.

tr.td: "HIGH PRESSURE FAULT" message on HMI screen.

td.para: Excessive HP operating pressure detected by the opening of the "HP PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS20).
The pressure read-out on the "MEMBRANES OUTLET PRESSURE GAUGE" (PI6) is greater than 68 bar.
Operating pressure is too high. If the fault persists despite correct adjustment of the pressure  problem on the HP measuring chain.
Loosen the "REGULATING VALVE" (PR2).
Loosen the "HP PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE" (PR2).
Re-start and re-adjust the operating pressure by means of the "REGULATING VALVE" (PR2).
The pressure read-out on the "MEMBRANES OUTLET PRESSURE GAUGE" (Pi6) must not exceed 68 bar.
Re-adjust the trigger level to 68 bar, or replace the “PRESSURE SWITCH” (PS20) if adjustment is not possible.

tr.td: In RINSING MODE, there is no water coming in.

td.para: There is no water coming from the network.
The flushing valve (SV1) remains closed.
Check that there is no valve closed upstream.
Check that the flushing valve (SV1) is powered.
-> If not, Run the cycle once again, If the problem persists, PLC connections to be checked.
-> If it is, the valve is defective and need to be replaced.

tr.td: In PRODUCTION cycle, “HIGH CONDUCTIVITY FAULT" in HMI.

td.para: High salinity of the permeate water.
Total salinity is correct, but the fault persists, check the salinity measuring chain.
Restart and check that the applied pressure is correct (between 45 and 65 bar) and that the permeate flow is reestablished.
Check the evolution of the conductivity, if all is correct then the “High conductivity fault” on HMI goes off, and the "PRODUCTION VALVE" (SV2) switches open.
Check the permeate salinity of each membrane with a portable calibrated salinity meter.
Fix or replace the "CONDUCTIVITY METER” and its cell.

tr.td: "GENERAL FAULT” is on. "HIGH PRESSURE BRINE FAULT" message on HMI screen.

td.para: Upstream valves in the brine reject line may be closed.
Installation of check valve CV5 is wrong.
Pressure switch PS30 is faulty.
PLC error.
Loosen the "SERVO MOTOR CONTROL VALVE" (PR2).
Open the upstream valve (yard scope).
Correct the installation direction of CV 5.
Correct the setting of the pressure switch PS30. If pressure Switch is defective, replace the switch.
Replace PLC / Program.

tr.td: “HIGH PRESSURE PERMEATE FAULT” message on HMI.

td.para: Valve V10, V11 of Neutralite filters are closed.
Pressure Switch PS40 is defective or which opening threshold is very low.
Loosen the "REGULATING VALVE" (PR2).
Open the Neutralite filter valves.
Correct the opening threshold set point of PS 40. Replace switch if defective.
Valve V8, V9 of Neutralite filters are closed..
Pressure Switch PS40 is defective or which opening threshold is very low.
Open the Neutralite filter valves.
Correct the opening threshold set point of PS 40. Replace switch if defective.
Permeate flow is higher than the designed permeate flow 1650 LPH.
Set point of flow switch FS10 is low.
FS10 is defective.
Defective membranes / membrane seals.
Reduce the pressure to reduce the permeate flow, there may be temperature increment or low TDS of feed water causing this high permeate flow. Correct the set point of FS10.
Replace FS10.
Rectify membrane installation or change membrane.
DPS 10 detected clogging of sand filter.
Defective DPS 10 or setting error.
Perform sand filter washing.
Correct the DPS 10 setting, if defective replace switch.

tr.td: “25 μ CARTRIDGE FILTER CLOGGED” alarm on HMI

td.para: DPS 20 detected clogging of 25μ cartridge.
Defective DPS 20 or setting error.
Replace 25μ cartridge.
Correct the DPS 20 setting, if defective replace switch.

tr.td: “5μ CARTRIDGE FILTER CLOGGED” alarm on HMI.

td.para: DPS 30 detected clogging of 5-micron cartridge.
Defective DPS 30 or setting error.
Replace 5-micron cartridge.
Correct the DPS 30 setting, if defective replace switch.

tr.td: “DOSING TANK LOW LEVEL” alarm on HMI.

td.para: Liquid in the dosing tanks is low in level.
Defective level switch LLS3 / LLS 4 Connection error.
Refill the tank with anti-scalant liquid.
Correct the connection of LLS3/LLS4 Replace switch if defective.

tr.td: In CIP mode, “CIP TANK LOW LEVEL “alarm on HMI.

td.para: Water in the CIP tank is low in level.
Defective level switch LLS1 or Connection error.
Refill the tank with chemical contained water as informed in CIP procedure.
Correct the connection of LLS1 or Replace switch if defective.

tr.td: Fresh water tank causing over flow, fresh water pump does not start even the control panel contactor is OK.

td.para: Connection error of level switches LLS2 and HLS1.
Defective switches LLS2 and HLS1.
Correct the connection of switches.
Replace if defective.

tr.td: Unusual pressure fluctuations at the discharge of the "HP PUMP" (P20).

td.para: Head loss from the PULSATION DAMPENER when back flowing. Defective PULSATION DAMPENER.
"HP PUMP" (P20) valves damaged or worn.
Before doing anything with the unit, isolate the electricity supply.
Check the bottle load, reload or replace the bottle.
See checking the Pulsation Dampener inflation. Refer page no.37
Stop the plant and repair. See page no.39
Low oil level (Check the service manual).
Water in the oil.
Worn internal parts of the case.
Before doing anything with the unit, isolate the electricity supply.
Refill up to the mark.
Change the oil. See page no.35
Replace the valves and seals of the HP pump. See page no.39.
Replace the valves and seals of the HP pump according to page no.39,

tr.td: The "HP PUMP" (P20) doesn’t achieve its nominal pressure.

td.para: The "REGULATING VALVE" (PR2) is defective.
Before doing anything with the unit, isolate the electricity supply.
Overhaul the “SERVO MOTOR CONTROL VALVE “(PR2). Replace if necessary.
With loss of seawater flow while increasing pressure.
Internal leakage in the backflow head of the "HP PUMP" (P20). HP gaskets worn or leakage in the pump body.

tr.td: Replace the valves and seals of the HP pump according to page no.39.

td.para: Before doing anything with the unit, isolate the electricity supply.
Check the booster pressure of the filtration line and the correct operation of the "LP SEAWATER PRESSURE SWITCH" (PS10), which should prevent the starting of the HP PUMP MOTOR.

tr.td: High conductivity of the water produced (comes gradually).

td.para: Change in temperature or salinity of the seawater.
Fouled RO membrane.
Check the nominal parameters in light of the new conditions and re-adjust the operational pressure with the help of the "REGULATING VALVE" (PR2).
Undertake cleaning of the membranes. See page no.24.

tr.td: No output of permeate water towards the production despite correct conductivity and a flow reading on the "PERMEATE FLOW METER" (FL2)

td.para: The "PERMEATE WATER DISTRIBUTION VALVE" (SV2) is either not driven or defective.
Feedback from conductivity meter is not available.
Before doing anything with the unit, isolate the electricity supply.
Replace the solenoid valve SV2.
Check that the conductivity meter connections and probe connections. Check the meter is correctly powered. If everything is ok with conductivity meter.
Then, Calibration from PLC has to be done.

tr.td: The unit is stopped and a pressure gauge indicates a pressure different from zero.

td.para: Stop the unit.
Replace the pressure gauge.
Stop the unit.
Adjust the water-tightness of the coupling and replace the seals.

tr.td:
Stop the unit.
Adjust the collar or replace the tube.
In production mode, Pressure not getting increased.
Regulating valve PR2 is not functioning.

td.para: Check the command to valve from PLC.
Check the measuring chain of valve open and close feedback from valve.
Defective valve. Repair or replace the valve.

tr.td: 100 ml Pack for 100 Liters of water.
To be selected by customer based upon routine of non- operation of RO.
Each kit contains 2.5 Kg of MC3 & 5 Kg of MC11.
HP Pump Oil / Feed pump oil

note.para: Note: Consumption of chemicals, consumables and life of membranes are depending upon proper operation, maintenance and feed water quality.

content.para: Kindly carry out all preventive /Corrective maintenance as per schedules.
Use proper tools and genuine spares
Do not carry out maintenance when equipment is running. SHUT OFF THE UNIT
Check expiry date of applicable chemicals before use.
Check availability of spare forehand before opening of part/equipment.

ol.li: Hp pump crank case oil level check.
Hp pump Plunger lubrication to be done at once in a week.
Check the level of Neutralite (Rehardener) granules once in a week.

tr.td: Feed Pump Oil check and refill
Inspect Feed pump and replace seals and gaskets.
Dosing pump valves and diaphragm replacement

section.id: HP PUMP OIL LEVEL CHECKING AND FILLING

title.id: HP PUMP OIL LEVEL CHECKING AND FILLING

section.title: HP PUMP OIL LEVEL CHECKING AND FILLING

content.para: Periodicity: First 50hrs & there after every 500hrs.

td.para: Tools - Standard mechanical tools. Oil recovery tank Consumables.
HP Pump oil - CON.HP.236 – as per requirement.
Spare’s requirement: Drain plug with seal – PMP.HP.CAT.102-9,10

content.para: See diagram above. Take out the oil stick (3), clean it with clean cloth and put it back to take the measure. Take the stick out and check that the oil level is right, situated between the mini and maxi marks. Top up oil level if necessary.
Place the drainage tank under the drainage hole of pump (2). Take out drain plug, filling plug and drain oil. Scrap the seal of drain plug, place the plug with new seal.
Fill the pump with oil and ensure the correct oil level by seeing it through sight glass.

section.id: FEED PUMP OIL CHECK AND REFILL

title.id: FEED PUMP OIL CHECK AND REFILL

section.title: FEED PUMP OIL CHECK AND REFILL:-

content.para: Periodicity 200 hours.

td.para: Tools - Standard mechanical tools. Oil recovery tank Consumables.
Oil - CON.HP.236 – as per requirement.

content.para: Open filling cap of bearing case of pump. Fill or top up oil till the marking / vent cap installed on pump. Install the constant oil leveller to maintain the oil level always.
Clean the oil spillage with cloth.

section.id: REPLACEMENT OF 5 25 CARBON CARTRDIGE AND SEAL

title.id: REPLACEMENT OF 5 25 CARBIN CARTRDIGE AND SEAL

section.title: REPLACEMENT OF 5, 25 & CARBON CARTRDIGE AND SEAL

content.para: Periodicity: Approx.500 hours for 5- & 25-micron cartridges, 2000 hours for oil absorbent filter & 5000 hours for carbon cartridge.

td.para: Tools: Standard tools, Filter Spanner (FLT.SPR.149)

Spare Parts
FLT.CAR.141 – 20” 5 Micron filter – 1 no.
FLT.MIC.397 – 20’’ 25 Micron filter – 1 no.
FLT.CAR.103 – 10’’ 10 Micron Carbon filter – 1 no.
OL.FLT.101 – Oil filter cartridge.
SEAL.2005 – Housing Seal – 1 no.

content.para: Loose the filter housing (1) with the help of filter spanner.
Clean the filter housing, place the new cartridge (3). Make sure the cartridge position is correct.
Fix the housing seal (2) properly or change the seal if it was leaking before.
Tighten the filter housing with hand.
Check for leakages at first operation after cartridge change.
Tighten the cartridge filter if necessary.
Periodicity: Approx.2000 hours.

td.para: Tools: Standard tools,

Spare Parts
BAG.FLT.100 – 50-micron bag filter.

content.para: Remove the Tri clover clamp.
Remove the top cover.
Unscrew the tensioner handle and take out the Tensioner with handle.
Remove the retainer plate.
Replace the filter element with new one.
Place the retainer plate and tensioner.
Lock the tensioner plate properly into the locater.
Tighten the tensioner handle.
Place the top cover and fix the tri clover cover.

section.id: INSPECT FEED PUMP AND REPLACE SEALS AND GASKETS

title.id: INSPECT FEED PUMP AND REPLACE SEALS AND GASKETS

section.title: INSPECT FEED PUMP AND REPLACE SEALS AND GASKETS

content.para: Periodicity 2000 hours / 2 yearly

td.para: Tools: Standard
Spare Parts.

ul.li: Dismantle and inspect the feed pump internals.
Replace gaskets and seals.

content.para: Periodicity: 2500 hrs.

note.para: Note: Check the pressure is zero in the HP pressure gauge.

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical tool.
And Portable nitrogen charging kit DMP.KIT.200 with required adaptors.

content.para: Check the pressure when the dampener is cold
Take off the protective cap of threading.
Release slightly the CHC screw (G) of the dampener loading valve.
Place the loading kit on the head of dampener, swivel the gauge for easy reading. Screw the nut (H) tightly by hand.

Open the valve (G) progressively by using the needle (P); when the gauge needle starts moving, unscrew one more turn. The gauge now indicates the inflation pressure of the dampener. This pressure should be 39 bars (+ or -2).
If the pressure is more than 39 bar, then open the discharge valve (E) carefully until the nominal pressure of 37-39 bar reached
If the pressure is less than 37 bar, then dampener to be charged.
Connect the hose to pressure reducing valve of nitrogen cylinder using the adapter.
Make a nitrogen flush to blow down the air in the hose.
Connect the hose to the loading kit.
Open the nitrogen cylinder carefully and load the dampener with nitrogen until 46 bar.
Close the nitrogen cylinder and disconnect the hose.
Release the excess pressure by opening hand wheel P.
Remove the charging kit and put the cap back.
Periodicity: 2500 hrs.

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical tools.
Spares Parts: PLY.BLT.300 Notched Belt 1no.

content.para:
Dismantling
Untighten the 2 fixing bolts (A) of HP Pump
Unscrew the position adjusting screw (B) of HP pump at the front side.
Slide the pump towards front.
Remove the old belt.
Fix a new belt.
Tighten the position adjusting screw (B) to achieve appropriate belt tension.
Tighten the 2 fixing (A) bolts of HP pump.
Periodicity: 5000 hrs

note.para: Note: check valves housings (157) can be kept in the cylinder head when dismantling.

content.para: In this case remove them by hand (Fig.5).

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical tools.
Torque wrench 0 to 5 da Nm.
Spares Parts:
Valve Kit – PMP.HP.CAT.102-80- 2 NOS.

ul.li: See diagram HP Pump (Diagram 1 to 7) and drawing.
Disconnect the hoses which are connected to the pump.
Remove the belt cover and the belt.
Remove the HP pump to operate on a work bench.
Take off the 8 screws (188) and washers (186) of the manifold (185) (Fig.1).
Hold up the underside of the manifold and using a mallet, tap the rear of the manifold (185) so as to separate it from the suction manifold (110) - (Fig.2).
Place the discharge manifold on a work table, crankcase side towards the top (Fig.3).
Take off the three-relief valve spacer (157) and the three inlet valve adapters (150) with the help of two screwdrivers as shown in figure 5.
Then take off the O-rings from the valve seats (165), the seats (164), the valves (166), the springs (167) and the casings (168). (Fig.6 – discharge line) (Fig;7 – suction line).

note.para: Note: For suction or discharge these components are identical.

ul.li: To make reassembly easier, keep the components in their dismantling order.
Scrap all the seals and check valves.
Clean all the components with a brush and cloth and grease removal solvent.
Place the crankcase side of the discharge manifold towards the top on the work table.
Place the new spring casings (168) into the valve chamber grooves.
Insert the new springs (167) into the casings.
Install the valves (166) underneath the springs with the undercut (hollow) towards the down side.
Install the new valve seats (164) with concave part turned towards the downside.
Place the O-rings (165) into the groove at the back of the valve seats.

Replace the 2 O-rings (155) of the relief valve spacers (157), lubricate the exterior part of the spacer and press it completely into the valve chamber with the smallest diameter to the down side of the manifold.
Replace the O-rings (143) and (154) on the inlet valve adapters (150) and place the adapters in the valve chamber with the small diameter O-ring towards the outside.
Replace the discharge manifold on to the suction manifold and tap with a mallet to adjust the manifolds.
Re-install the 8 screws with washers.
Tighten to 40 Nm in the order indicated by the figure 14.
Remount the pump, the belt, the pipes and the hoses

content.para: Periodicity: 5000 hrs.

note.para: Note: The high-pressure seal (125) might leap when reassembling.

content.para: To install it again use the valve housing of the relief valve (157). Press it in position.

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical tools. Torque wrench 0 to 5 da Nm.
Spare parts: Seal Kit – PMP.HP.CAT.102-81- 1 No.

content.para: See board HP PUMP 2531 (Diag.1 to 7) and drawing

ul.li: To replace HP (125) and LP (106) seals the discharge manifold (185) and suction has to be removed. Use the check valves visit to carry out the two operations at the same time.
Remove the 4 screws (117) of the discharge manifold (185) (Fig. 8).
Hand-turn the crankshaft (if necessary, take off the belt protector) to separate the suction manifold (110) from the pump casing (53) (Fig. 9).

Support the suction manifold (110) underneath and tap the back with a mallet to unfasten the discharge manifold (185). Keep correct alignment not to damage the ceramic plungers (90) of the pump (fig.10).
Place the casing side of the suction manifold (110) on the work table and using outside circlip pliers, remove the HP seals (125) (Fig. 11)
Turn the manifold over on the work table and remove the low-pressure seals (106) (Fig.12)
Check the ceramic plungers and make sure there are no splits or cavitation marks.
Grease the new low-pressure seals (106) and put them back, spring turned downwards, pressing slightly.
Turn the manifold over. Replace seals (125) with new ones and grease them. Put them back with the « V » side turned upwards.
Grease the ceramic plungers lightly and slip the overhauled suction manifold (110) carefully over the plungers to adjust it against the casing (53).
Place the 4 screws (117) and tighten with a torque wrench to 40 Nm.

content.para: To finish remounting the pump, go to Title 3.3Replacement of the six valves of the HP Pump 2531 (see previously in subject 1).
Periodicity: 5000 hrs.

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical tools
Spare parts: HP pump head - PMP.HP.CAT.102-81-31 – 1 no.

content.para:
Removing the HP pump head
Drain the HP pump.
Disconnect the hoses which are connected to the pump.
Remove the belt cover and the belt.
Remove the HP pump to operate on a work bench.
Remove the 4 screws who retain the HP pump head to the rest of the body pump.
Remove the HP pump head. Warning: not to damage the ceramic plunger.

ul.li: Place the new HP pump head, be careful with the ceramic plunger.
Place the 4 screws of the HP pump head.
Place the pump with the belt, connect the hoses to the pump.
Prepare 2.5 liter of new oil according to the range model and fill the oil pan
(See page no.35)

content.para: Periodicity: 5000 hrs.

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical tools
Spare parts: Dosing pump maintenance kit-DOS-100-3

ul.li: Make system pressure less.
Empty the dosing head.
Switch of the main supply.
Safely collect the existing liquid from pump.
Dismantle suction and pressure hoses.
Dismantle valve on suction and discharge side (5,6).
Remove the cover (9)
Loosen screws (8) on the dosing head (7) and remove the screws and discs.
Removing the dosing head (7).
Unscrew diagram (4) counter-clockwise and remove with flange (2).
Start reassembling, attach flange (2), correctly and screw diaphragm (4) clockwise.
Make sure that the O ring 3 is seated correctly.
Connect / switch the main supply.
Turn the adjustment knob, slowly to bring the diaphragm into its service position ‘inside’ (end of suction phase, diaphragm retracted). Set adjustment knob back to 0 %.
Switch off mains supply again.
Attach the dosing head (7)
Install screws with discs (8) and cross-tighten – Torque: 3 Nm
Attach the cover (9).
Install new valves (5, 6).
Do not interchange valves and pay attention to direction of arrow
Connect suction, pressure and de-aeration hoses
De-aerate dosing pump

content.para: Periodicity: 10000 hrs.

td.para: Tools: Standard mechanical & Torque wrench 0 to 50 Nm
Spares Parts:

ol.li: FTT.ORING.427 O ring inter connector 16 nos
FTT.ORING.426 Plug external o ring 20 nos
FTT.ORING.427 Plug internal o ring 20 nos

td.para: Consumables: Silicone food grade grease.

ul.li: Disconnect the HP hoses at inlet and outlet of pressure vessels.
Disconnect the permeate outlet on each vessel.
Remove the counter-nut, nuts and washers of the tie rods.
Remove the housing flanges FTT.368 and the tie-rods MBR.TIE.368.
Remove the end plugs MBR.HOS.367.1 & 367.2 and inter-connetors MBR.HOS.363.3.
Take out the membranes MBR.ELE.169 of the vessels by pushing them in the sea water direction in each vessel as far as possible.
Replace all the O-rings FTT.ORING.426 & 427 on the plugs and vessel interconnectors. Grease all the seals with a little silicone food grease.
Place a new membrane in the first vessel by entering it on the opposite side to its lip seal and in the normal sea water circulation direction as far as possible.
Repeat the same reassembly on the other vessels considering the sea water path direction.
Then place the two pairs on inter-membrane plugs with their interconnector and put the plus into membrane housing MBR.HOS.170.
Put back the housing flanges and the tie-rods.
Put back the washers, nuts and the counter-nut together and increasingly tightening the tie-bolts by applying an even torque of 15 Nm.
Re-connect the HP and permeate hoses to shut the hydraulic system.
